author: Reuters
title: Cambodia 'upcycler' turns tonnes of plastic bottles into brooms | Nasdaq
text: By Chantha Lach PHNOM PENH, Feb 16 (Reuters) - In a small warehouse in Cambodia's capital, a group of workers sit and spin waste plastic bottles into strips, turning them into bristles for brooms, of which they churn out 500 each day. For the past 11 months they have transformed around 40 tonnes of discarded plastic bottles, about 5,000 bottles per day, by "upcycling" them into brooms they say are more robust than regular brushes. Those sell for 10,000 riel ($2.50) and 15,000 riel ($3.75) each. Plastic strips from the empty bottles are collected into a bundle on a machine, before being softened in hot water and sliced evenly to be sewn with metal wires into the ends of a bamboo stick. Cambodian entrepreneur Has Kea, 41, wants to reduce plastic pollution in his community, in a city that produces up to 38,000 tonnes of all types of waste each day, according to its environmental department. About a fifth of that is single-use plastic that ends up in landfills and waterways. "This broom is quite solid, not easy to break," said Suon Kosal, a 26-year-old Buddhist monk whose temple bought 80 of the brooms last month. Kea buys empty plastic bottles from trash collectors and garbage depots. With the seemingly endless supply, he is confident about the longevity of his business. He is also open to competitors stepping in to the market. "This also help reduce pollution to the environment and encourages people to collect plastic bottles to sell to us at a higher price, which in turn, could earn them a better living," he said. (Writing by Juarawee Kittisilpa; Editing by Martin Petty and Alison Williams) The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.

author: Irishexaminer.com (digitaldesk@irishexaminer.com)
title: Rain helps firefighters slow New Mexico blazes as Biden approves disaster relief
text:
More than 1,000 firefighters in the US state of New Mexico took advantage of a break in the weather to gain the upper hand â€“ for now â€“ on a pair of wildfires that have killed two people, destroyed hundreds of homes and forced thousands to flee.
President Joe Biden issued a disaster declaration for parts of southern New Mexico, freeing up funding and more resources as crews worked to keep the flames from spreading.
Their efforts have received a boost from a storm system that brought with it rain, hail and cooler temperatures to the mountain village of Ruidoso and other parts of the state.
â€œThe fire has lost momentum,â€ Arthur Gonzales, the fire behaviour analyst for the federal attack team, told residents at a community meeting in Alamogordo on Thursday night.
â€œWe still have a lot of work to do, but itâ€™s really changed that fire behaviour,â€ he added, noting that very little growth in the blaze is expected over the next few days.
But firefighters know this is a brief respite given the tinderbox conditions that helped fuel the fires in the first place.
Within days, the fires have consumed an area half the size of Washington, DC.
â€œWhat weâ€™re really focusing on now at this point is: when might we see this return to active fire spread?â€ Mr Gonzales said. â€œIs there potential for this to start picking up and moving again?â€
Federal and local officials said evacuation orders likely would remain in place for days in some places as crews snuff out hot spots around Ruidoso. Law enforcement officers are also patrolling the streets to keep potential looters away.
Despite some reports that the fires were caused by human activity, federal incident commander Dave Gessar said the causes are under investigation and remain â€œundeterminedâ€.
The federal disaster declaration will help with recovery efforts, including temporary housing, low-cost loans to cover uninsured property and other emergency work in Lincoln County and on lands belonging to the Mescalero Apache Tribe.
Residents fled the larger of the two fires with little notice as it swept into neighbourhoods on Monday.
More areas were evacuated on Tuesday as the fire ballooned, consuming homes nestled among the the ponderosa pines that dominate the hillsides.
An estimated 1,400 structures have been destroyed or damaged, and Ruidoso mayor Lynn Crawford has estimated about half of these were homes. Whole portions of some communities were lost, he said.
â€œThese are things that are burnt to the foundations and all the trees around it,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s devastating.â€
Authorities say a 60-year-old man who died was found near the popular Swiss Chalet Inn in Ruidoso. His
family said he had arranged for a lift from friends but they were unable to get to him on Monday since the roads were blocked. It appeared he was overcome after he tried to set out on foot.
On Wednesday, officers discovered the skeletal remains of an unidentified second person in the driverâ€™s seat of a burned vehicle.
The ongoing heatwave will likely spread to the Mid/Deep South and Southeast early next weekðŸ¥µ. Heat index values may exceed 110 degrees in some places.â€” National Weather Service (@NWS)
[https://t.co/DGeRdJ7516] [June 20, 2024]
A couple of residents have been driving around Ruidoso and neighbouring Alto, providing reports via social media of what they are seeing. There are locations where the ground was turned to ash, the trees were blackened and homes were reduced to their foundations, with only fireplaces remaining.
Much of the US south-west has been exceedingly dry and hot in recent months. Those conditions, along with strong winds, whipped the flames out of control, rapidly advancing the South Fork Fire into Ruidoso in a matter of hours. Evacuations extended to hundreds of homes, businesses, a regional medical centre and the Ruidoso Downs horse track.
Nationwide, wildfires have scorched more than 3,344 square miles this year â€“ a figure higher than the 10-year average, according to the National Interagency Fire Centre.
Nearly 20 wildfires burning in California, Arizona, Colorado and Washington state and elsewhere are considered large and uncontained.

author: penn_state
title: Broadcast police communications may pose priv | EurekAlert!
text: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa. â€” Police radio transmissions contain personally identifiable information that could pose privacy risks for members of the public, especially Black males, according to a new study by researchers at Penn State and the University of Chicago. â€œThis study provides a window into police activity as events unfold,â€ said Shomir Wilson , associate professor of information sciences and technology at Penn State and study co-author. â€œWe found that because police radio transmissions disproportionately involve Black suspects, thereâ€™s a proportionally higher privacy risk for Black people in these communications.â€ The researchers studied a total of 24 hours of human-transcribed and annotated broadcast police communications transmitted on a single day in three Chicago dispatch zones, or regions used to coordinate police activity. According to U.S. census data, one zone was majority non-Hispanic white, one majority Hispanic and one majority non-Hispanic Black. The team found that broadcast police communications mentioned males nine times more frequently than females and that Black males were most often mentioned of all groups, even in the majority white zone. The researchers presented their findings at the 27th Association for Computing Machinery Conference on Computer-Supported Cooperative Work and Social Computing on Nov. 9-13 in Costa Rica. The team received a diversity, equity and inclusion recognition from the conferenceâ€™s awards committee. â€œThe typical police radio transmission is short and serves a coordinating purpose, something like â€˜Car 54, where are you?â€™â€ said Chris Graziul , research assistant professor at the University of Chicago, study co-author and one of two principal investigators leading the project. â€œThese transmissions try to communicate whatâ€™s happening and describe whoâ€™s involved. In the process, sensitive information is often disclosed.â€ The researchers obtained 9,115 transmissions â€” what they called â€œutterancesâ€ â€” that occurred when police or dispatch communicated via radio broadcast. They manually transcribed the transmissions and then randomly chose 2,000 utterances from across the three zones to analyze further. They developed a qualitative annotation scheme to label the text. They divided the annotated data into six categories, ranging from event information, such as â€œresidential alarm break in" or â€œtraffic stop,â€ and procedural transmissions, such as the â€œcar 54â€ example, to casual transmissions like â€œMorning, squad.â€ The researchers found that event utterances contained the most references â€” about 60% â€” to gender, race/ethnicity, age and protected health information, which can be used to identify individuals. Nearly 68% of utterances that included a sociodemographic indicator used male gendered terms, and approximately 69% of those utterances referred to Black people, according to the researchers. â€œOur findings contribute to a larger body of evidence about racial disparities in policing. What is novel here is the data source: radio transmissions,â€ Graziul said. â€œDespite prolific use by police systems around the world, few have explored what this means of communication can tell us about how policing operates in practice. Disproportionate mentions of Black people reflect a novel way to observe how officersâ€™ attention is unevenly distributed across racial/ethnic groups, and identifying this disparity helps us understand challenges to the ethical use of this data source for research, like preventing leakage of sensitive personal information, which would impact Black communities substantially more than other communities.â€ After examining the utterances, the team tested a large language model (LLM), a widely used artificial intelligence tool, to determine its capacity to find personal information in the transcripts. Despite the unique nature of the language involved with broadcast police communications, the LLM detected personally identifiable information with high accuracy, highlighting the risk of privacy vulnerability. Bad actors, such as identity thieves, could use AI technology to quickly find and misuse the personal information in transcripts of police radio activity, according to the researchers. â€œThis work reveals a concerning trend of racial inequality in terms of the exposure of sensitive information during police radio transmissions,â€ said Pranav Narayanan Venkit , graduate student pursuing a doctoral degree in informatics in the College of Information Sciences and Technology and first author on the paper. â€œThis study may help researchers and developers give more thought to interactions between LLM and different segments of society â€” the policing community, minority populations and various other populations â€” to identify biases and protect personal information.â€ Miranda Goodman, who graduated with her bachelorâ€™s degree from Penn State this past summer, and fourth-year Penn State student Samantha Kenny also contributed to this work. The National Institute of Minority Health and Health Disparities of the National Institutes of Health supported this work. This research was also supported by the Urban Resiliency Initiative, which is led by Margaret Beale Spencer, distinguished professor emerita at the University of Chicago and a principal investigator of this larger project. DOI Article Title Race and Privacy in Broadcast Police Communications Article Publication Date 8-Nov-2024

author: /autor/leysa-caro-gonzalez/
title: Jenniffer GonzÃ¡lez: â€œQue sea la voluntad de Dios y que el pueblo vote y seleccione lo mejor para Puerto Ricoâ€ - El Nuevo DÃ­a
text: La precandidata a la gobernaciÃ³n del PNP sostuvo, tras votar en Carolina, que es la mejor opciÃ³n para Puerto Rico, frente al incumbente Pedro Pierluisi 2 de junio de 2024 - 3:09 PM La precandidata a la gobernaciÃ³n del PNP sostuvo, tras votar en Carolina, que es la mejor opciÃ³n para Puerto Rico, frente al incumbente Pedro Pierluisi 2 de junio de 2024 - 3:09 PM Nota del editor: no te pierdas ni un detalle de cara a las elecciones del 2024 en Puerto Rico. [Visita nuestro sitio especial](https://www.elnuevodia.com/especiales/elecciones-2024/) para mantenerte informado y [regÃ­strate aquÃ­ en el boletÃ­n Pulso PolÃ­tico](https://www.elnuevodia.com/newsletters/pulso-politico/). --- Carolina - Tras hacer una marca bajo su nombre y el de [Elmer RomÃ¡n](https://www.elnuevodia.com/topicos/elmer-roman/), a quien apoya como compaÃ±ero de papeleta, la precandidata a la gobernaciÃ³n por el [Partido Nuevo Progresista](https://www.elnuevodia.com/topicos/pnp/) (PNP), [Jenniffer GonzÃ¡lez](https://www.elnuevodia.com/topicos/jenniffer-gonzalez/), se expresÃ³ confiada este domingo en que â€œel puebloâ€ le darÃ¡ la victoria en la contienda frente al incumbente [Pedro Pierluisi](https://www.elnuevodia.com/topicos/pedro-pierluisi/). â€œEl pueblo me lo pidiÃ³, mi base de partido me lo pidiÃ³. Estuve en la calle, estuve en la isla visitando por mÃ¡s de un aÃ±o, y ese fue el sentir del pueblo. TodavÃ­a, al dÃ­a de hoy, veo ese respaldo en la calle, asÃ­ que, aquÃ­ estamos y, ahora, le compete la voluntad al pueblo de Puerto Rico. Yo aceptÃ© el reto que el pueblo me dio; ahora, es solamente acatar la voluntad del pueblo y de Diosâ€, aseverÃ³. Fue casi al filo de la 1:00 p.m. que GonzÃ¡lez llegÃ³ a votar a la escuela Salvador Brau, en Carolina, junto a su esposo, JosÃ© YovÃ­n Vargas, y su madre, Nydia ColÃ³n. Tras conversar con los medios de comunicaciÃ³n, se dirigiÃ³ al colegio de votaciÃ³n y, unos 15 minutos despuÃ©s, hizo pÃºblicas sus papeletas. â€œEstoy feliz. Mi partido, a mÃ­, me ha dado muchas oportunidades. Yo fui presidenta de la juventud (estadista) a los 14 aÃ±os de edad y jamÃ¡s esperÃ© que un dÃ­a yo fuera a estar en la papeleta a la gobernaciÃ³n, y hoy el tiempo, el pueblo y Dios me han llevado hasta aquÃ­. AsÃ­ que, que sea la voluntad de Dios y que el pueblo vote y seleccione lo mejor para Puerto Ricoâ€, dijo GonzÃ¡lez tras la votaciÃ³n. La madre de GonzÃ¡lez dijo estar un poco â€œansiosaâ€. â€œEsto estÃ¡ en manos de papa Dios, porque Ã‰l es quien decide todo, pero yo confÃ­o en que ella va ser electa y que va a cumplir con todo, porque ella conoce las necesidades de nuestro pueblo, y para eso se ha preparadoâ€, dijo ColÃ³n. Fue el 28 de septiembre de 2023 cuando GonzÃ¡lez hizo pÃºblico su interÃ©s en aspirar por la candidatura a la gobernaciÃ³n por el PNP, retando asÃ­ al gobernador Pierluisi. En aquel entonces, dijo, en un mensaje grabado, que Puerto Rico iba â€œpor mal caminoâ€, una expresiÃ³n que provocÃ³ reacciones adversas entre miembros de la colectividad. Hoy, casi nueve meses despuÃ©s, GonzÃ¡lez sostiene que ella es la mejor opciÃ³n para el paÃ­s. â€œCuando anunciÃ© mi candidatura, hablÃ© de un cambio para Puerto Rico, hablÃ© de un gobierno que le resuelva a la gente, de un gobierno Ã¡gil, de un gobierno con sentido de urgencia y sensibilidad, y hoy es el dÃ­a que el pueblo de Puerto Rico tiene para escoger, a mi juicio, la gran diferenciaâ€, puntualizÃ³. â€œSi quiere quedarse como estÃ¡, con los apagones, con los aumentos en el agua, con los aumentos en la luz, o si quiere un gobierno que le resuelva, y eso es lo que se vota hoy. Si quieren quedarse como estÃ¡n, pues, estÃ¡ la opciÃ³n del gobernador y si quieren una opciÃ³n de cambio, estÃ¡ el capitÃ¡n Elmer RomÃ¡n y esta servidoraâ€, subrayÃ³. A pesar de los contratiempos surgidos durante la primera parte de la jornada, como las fallas en el servicio elÃ©ctrico y la supuesta falta de funcionarios de su campaÃ±a en algunos colegios de votaciÃ³n, GonzÃ¡lez se expresÃ³ confiada en que la intenciÃ³n de cada elector se harÃ¡ valer. â€œYo no tengo preocupaciÃ³n con eso. Antes, se votaba sin una mÃ¡quina y se sabÃ­an los resultadosâ€, expuso. â€œYo tengo ahÃ­, no solamente una baterÃ­a de abogados, sino voluntarios que estÃ¡n en las mesas y funcionarios de mi partido, que han estado histÃ³ricamente ahÃ­ defendiendo los votos de Pierluisi y de otra gente en las mÃºltiples elecciones. AsÃ­ que es el mismo grupo de trabajo que, en este momento, estamos enfrentados en unas primarias, pero luego de hoy, en noviembre, vamos todos juntos a una [elecciÃ³n general](https://www.elnuevodia.com/topicos/elecciones-2024/)â€, seÃ±alÃ³. GonzÃ¡lez rechazÃ³ las denuncias sobre la falta de funcionarios de colegio, y dijo que esas expresiones supuestamente forman parte de una estrategia de la oposiciÃ³n. â€œEn el caso mÃ­o, son todos voluntarios, no hay nadie obligadoâ€, expuso. Referente a los votos por adelantado y la incertidumbre que existe con la contabilizaciÃ³n de los sufragios que aÃºn no han sido recibidos en la [ComisiÃ³n Estatal de Elecciones](https://www.elnuevodia.com/topicos/comision-estatal-elecciones/), GonzÃ¡lez sostuvo que espera que el proceso culmine sin sombras. No obstante, dijo que cualquier alegaciÃ³n de fraude serÃ¡ analizada por su equipo electoral. â€œYo voy a hacer valer la ley y el reglamento para que se cuente cada voto y la intenciÃ³n del electorâ€, afirmÃ³. Un total de 122,001 electores solicitaron votar adelantado por correo: 84,240 del PNP y 37,761 del [Partido Popular DemocrÃ¡tico](https://www.elnuevodia.com/topicos/ppd/). A las denuncias hechas mÃ¡s temprano por el director de campaÃ±a del gobernador, [Edwin Mundo](https://www.elnuevodia.com/topicos/edwin-mundo/), quien alegÃ³ que representantes de GonzÃ¡lez en los colegios vestÃ­an camisetas alusivas a la campaÃ±a, en violaciÃ³n a lo establecido por la CEE, la precandidata reconociÃ³ que habÃ­an comprado unas â€œt-shirtsâ€ con el logo de la Palma. La situaciÃ³n, sin embargo, se resolviÃ³. En la tarde, GonzÃ¡lez participarÃ­a de una misa junto a su familia antes de acudir a su comitÃ© de campaÃ±a, en Hato Rey, a esperar los resultados finales. Te invitamos a descargar cualquiera de estos navegadores para ver nuestras noticias:

author: EFE
title: Detectado en Suecia el primer caso fuera de Ãfrica de la nueva variante de la viruela del mono
text: El primer caso fuera de \u00c1frica en el actual brote de mpox (antes conocido como viruela del mono) fue detectado este jueves en Suecia, inform\u00f3 el ministro de Asuntos Sociales sueco, Jakob Forssmed."Por supuesto es algo que tomamos en serio", declar\u00f3 en una rueda de prensa, seg\u00fan la agencia sueca TT.El caso ha sido detectado en la regi\u00f3n de Estocolmo y se trata de una persona que estuvo en la zona de \u00c1frica afectada por el brote.Sanidad reunir\u00e1 el lunes a las CCAA para analizar la emergencia sanitaria de la viruela del mono"La persona en Suecia ha recibido tratamiento y reglas de comportamiento (que debe seguir) seg\u00fan las recomendaciones actuales", declar\u00f3 Olivia Wigzell, directora general en funciones de la Agencia de Salud P\u00fablica.El caso no incrementa el riesgo de la poblaci\u00f3n sueca en general, afirm\u00f3 Wigzell, seg\u00fan la cual no hacen falta por el momento medidas de control de infecciones adicionales.La Organizaci\u00f3n Mundial de la Salud (OMS) declar\u00f3 este mi\u00e9rcoles el actual brote de mpox (conocido antes como viruela del mono) en la Rep\u00fablica Democr\u00e1tica del Congo (CDC), y que se ha extendido a otros pa\u00edses cercanos, como una emergencia de salud p\u00fablica de alcance internacional.\u00bfQu\u00e9 es, c\u00f3mo se transmite y cu\u00e1les son los s\u00edntomas de la viruela del mono?Esta es la segunda vez en dos a\u00f1os que se considera que esta enfermedad infecciosa puede convertirse en una amenaza sanitaria internacional, una alerta que inicialmente se levant\u00f3 en mayo del a\u00f1o pasado tras contenerse su propagaci\u00f3n y considerarse que la situaci\u00f3n estaba bajo control.La nueva variante puede contagiarse f\u00e1cilmente con un contacto estrecho entre dos individuos, sin que sea necesario un contacto sexual, y est\u00e1 considerada m\u00e1s peligrosa que la variante de 2022.

author: Megan Camponovo
title: Watch: Videos you may have missed this week
text: Watch: Videos you may have missed this week From a good Samaritan rescuing a pig that was "tossed like a football" along a Mardi Gras parade to a man being rescued two days after driving off a cliff, here are some of the videos you may have missed this week: Good Samaritan rescues pig 'tossed like a football' along Mardi Gras parade route A [piglet](/article/good-samaritan-rescues-pig-along-mardi-gras-parade-route/46963693) that was tossed around on a parade route during Mardi Gras has been rescued. A good Samaritan rescued the young pig after she saw three men tossing it around like a football at a park near the parade route. The pig, who now has a new name of "Piglet," was not hurt during the ordeal, but was very scared. Watch the video in the player above. Man rescued 2 days after driving off Big Sur cliffside in California A California man was [rescued](/article/watch-man-rescued-2-days-after-driving-off-big-sur-cliffside-in-california/60024861) on Tuesday after driving his car off a Big Sur cliffside and falling 400 feet. The man, who crashed while driving home from his job, was first reported missing after not returning home on Sunday night. Wild video shows man climbing Florida cellular tower to livestream on social media According to deputies, the Hillsborough County Sheriff's Office aviation unit was called around 7 p.m. on Feb. 24 after reports that an individual was [climbing a cellular tower](/article/florida-man-climbing-cellular-tower-video/46995065). HCSO said the individual was climbing back down the tower after livestreaming a video to his social media. The aviation team was able to direct ground deputies to the location of the climber. Handcuffed car theft suspect outruns officers in Philadelphia A Philadelphia [car theft suspect](/article/philadelphia-handcuffed-suspect-flees/46976306) who had his hands cuffed behind him fled from two police officers outside a hospital where he had been taken for examination, police said Monday. Puppy spotted along an interstate on-ramp in Boston quickly finds a new home A [young puppy](/article/puppy-found-interstate-on-ramp-rescued/46980204) that was recently found along an on-ramp heading toward Interstate 93 in Boston, Massachusetts, did not take long to find a new place to call home.

author: Redazione Web
title: Manovra, Confagricoltura: misure positive, il Milleproroghe dÃ  respiro alle imprese
text:
Manovra, Confagricoltura: misure positive, il Milleproroghe dÃ  respiro alle imprese 3 Minuti di Lettura VenerdÃ¬ 29 Dicembre 2023, 19:41 Confagricoltura apprezza le misure per il settore contenute nella manovra.
Â«Confagricoltura plaude a diverse misure a supporto del settore primario, inserite nella Legge di Bilancio; in particolare: il Fondo per la gestione delle emergenze in agricoltura che prevede lo stanziamento di 100 milioni di euro per ciascuno degli anni 2024, 2025 e 2026; il differimento, dal 1Â° gennaio 2024 al 1Â° luglio 2024, della decorrenza dellâ€™imposta sui manufatti in plastica monouso e dellâ€™imposta sul consumo delle bevande analcoliche edulcorateÂ», si legge in una nota.
Â«La manovra - prosegue l'associazione degli agricoltori guidata da Massimiliano Giansanti - risponde alle richieste della Confederazione in merito alla reintroduzione delle misure di intervento per la previsione della liquiditÃ  aziendale, al fine di evitare il sovraindebitamento. Significativo il sostegno alle imprese, tramite il finanziamento del credito di imposta per il Mezzogiorno (pari a 1,8 miliardi di euro); le dotazioni di bilancio per i contratti di sviluppo e le misure agevolative della cosiddetta â€œNuova Sabatiniâ€. Accolta anche la richiesta di intervento, da parte di Confagricoltura, per nuovi stanziamenti finalizzati alla ricostruzione dei territori interessati dai sismi degli anni scorsi e dagli eventi alluvionali manifestatesi dal 1Â° maggio 2023Â».
L'associazione di Palazzo della Valle auspica poi Â«un progressivo aumento degli interventi sistemici a vantaggio del sistema imprese, guardando con favore allâ€™incentivazione di ogni azione che possa favorire la ripresa dei consumi. Bene, dunque, lâ€™introduzione del â€œBonus spesaâ€, cosiddetto â€œSocial Cardâ€, che puÃ² stimolare lâ€™acquisto di prodotti dellâ€™agricoltura italianaÂ». Si sottolinea, infine, Â«la necessitÃ  di uno sforzo ulteriore su alcuni temi: la reintroduzione dellâ€™Irpef (che possa almeno avvenire in modo graduale), la gestione del rischio in agricoltura e la tassazione retroattiva in relazione ai contratti di superficieÂ».
Confagricoltura giudica positivamente anche le norme del decreto-legge Milleproroghe. Eâ€™ il caso - rileva ancora l'organizzazione - della proroga al 31 dicembre 2024 della possibilitÃ  di rinviare i controlli sulla regolaritÃ  contributiva (Durc), da parte delle amministrazioni competenti, al momento del saldo in caso di erogazione di aiuti e contributi pubblici. Analoga possibilitÃ  viene prevista in materia di inadempienza rispetto allâ€™obbligo di versamento derivante dalla notifica di una o piÃ¹ cartelle di pagamento da parte dellâ€™Agenzia delle Entrate. In tal caso il pagamento in anticipo Ã¨ sottoposto a clausola risolutiva e quindi al recupero dei benefici erogati.
Â«Positiva - rileva Confagricoltura - anche la proroga al 2024 per lâ€™applicazione delle misure di contenimento della Xylella fastidiosa nel comparto olivicolo. Il decreto Milleproroghe - aggiunge la Confederazione - ha anche esteso al 31 dicembre 2024 (era al 31.12.23) il termine per la revisione delle macchine agricole immatricolate dal 1Â° gennaio 1984 al 31 dicembre 1996, e al 31 dicembre 2025 (era al 31.12.24) la scadenza per la revisione di quelle immatricolate dal 1Â° gennaio 1997 al 31 dicembre 2019. La proroga - evidenzia Confagricoltura - si Ã¨ resa ancora una volta necessaria perchÃ© non Ã¨ stato ancora emanato il dm che dovrÃ  stabilire la tipologia di verifiche da effettuare in sede di revisione e, soprattutto, lâ€™impostazione organizzativa dei centri di revisione. Per cui ad oggi, non Ã¨ possibile procedere alla revisione delle macchine agricole>.
Â«Confagricoltura apprezza inoltre le misure volte a estendere i termini degli strumenti giÃ  individuati per mitigare gli effetti della siccitÃ  sulle coltivazioni - si legge ancora in una nota dell'associazione -. Le proroghe inserite nel decreto-legge approvato dal Consiglio dei ministri danno respiro alle imprese - conclude Confagricoltura -. Si ribadisce, tuttavia, la necessitÃ  di interventi strutturali piÃ¹ ampi a favore dellâ€™agricoltura italiana e delle sue aziende, per dare slancio al settore e allâ€™economia del PaeseÂ».
